This Report was prepared by a team consisting of P. Chang, Principal Education Specialist,
MKSS (Team Leader); Y. Uehara, Senior Social Development Specialist, MKOC; A. Bauer,
Senior Economist (Poverty Reduction), RSPR; C. Ouch, Program Officer (Social Sectors),
CARM; and K. Emzita, Counsel, OGC.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In support of gender and development (GAD) in Cambodia, the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  provided  technical  assistance1  (TA)  to  help  formulate  the  National  Policy  for 
Women (issued in 1996) and establish the Ministry of Women’s Affairs (in 1998, the ministry 
was expanded to include veterans’ affairs and was renamed the Ministry of Women’s and 
Veterans’  Affairs  [MOWVA]  in  1999).  MOWVA  plays  a  catalytic  role  within  the  Royal 
Government of Cambodia (the Government) to mainstream gender in the mandates, policies, 
and programs of line ministries, local governments, public institutions, civil society, and private 
sector.  MOWVA  also  collaborates  with  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  through  the 
Women’s Forum and coordinates all external assistance for GAD. 
 
2.  A second TA2 provided capacity-building support to enable MOWVA to influence and 
guide the line ministries and lower level administration units to mainstream gender concerns. 
Implementation of the TA commenced in May 2000 and was completed in October 2001. The 
TA completion report rates the activity successful. The Government requested a follow-up TA to 
bring the newly acquired expertise to the grassroots level in the rural areas and initiate activities 
for the economic empowerment of women. The current TA is included in ADB’s country strategy 
and program (CSP) for 2002. It supports poverty reduction interventions for disadvantaged 
women, one of the priorities for cooperation between the Government and ADB as formalized in 
the poverty reduction partnership agreement signed on 29 July 2002. A TA fact-finding mission 
visited Cambodia in March 2002 and reached an understanding with the Government on the 
objectives, scope, cost estimates, implementation arrangements, and consulting services for the 
TA.3 The logical framework for the TA is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Cambodia’s gross domestic product per capita is estimated at only 257 (US) dollars in 
2000,  among  the  lowest  in  the  region.  The  incidence  of  poverty  is  high,  with  36.1%  of 
households living below the poverty line. Cambodia has one of the highest female labor force 
participation rates in the region, at 73.5% of women over the age of 15 years. Women comprise 
54% of skilled workers in agriculture, 75% of the primary labor force in wholesale and retail, and 
67% of the labor force in manufacturing. The adult literacy rate is 61% (vs. 83% for males), and 
only 12% of women over 25 years have more than a primary school education. The total fertility 
rate at 4.1 and maternal mortality ratio at 473 per 100,000 live births (2000) are the highest in 
the region. Cambodia has become a sending, receiving, and transit country for trafficking of 
women and children. The Second Socioeconomic Development Plan, 2001-2005, estimates that 
88,000 Cambodian women are in Thailand, with 40–60% of sex workers saying they were 
forced or tricked into the business. As of 2000, 31% of commercial sex workers and 2.3% of 
women attending antenatal clinics were infected with HIV/AIDS.4 Poverty, social upheaval, 
underdeveloped legal infrastructure, and weak law enforcement contribute to the exploitation of 
women. 
 
4.  While MOWVA has improved its technical and managerial capacity considerably over 
recent years, much is still to be desired to fortify its role as advocate, catalyst, and facilitator of 
gender mainstreaming and awareness of gender concerns. Staff in MOWVA’s central offices 
have been upgraded, but staff at the provincial, district, and commune levels, who number over 
1,000 and comprise the bulk of the ministry’s human resources, have gone largely untrained.

MOWVA’s middle management is inadequate. MOWVA does not have adequate resources to 
support gender focal points in the line ministries, and coordination is still unsatisfactory and 
ineffective.  Findings  in  many  impact  evaluation  studies  of  ADB’s  Operations  Evaluation 
Department show that to ensure sustained development, a series of overlapping projects with 
consistent core objectives, aiming over a decade or more, is needed to make an impact on key 
indicators while strengthening government management capacity. 
 
5.  The participating line ministries need strengthened capacity to (i) gather information and 
analyze  gender  concerns  in  employment  directed  at  influencing  policy  formulation  and 
integration of gender concerns, especially as they affect the poor into sector policies and 
programs; (ii) identify and respond to gender concerns in their areas of responsibility; and (iii) 
establish systems and procedures within the ministry for sectorwide management of women’s 
economic  empowerment  activities.  The  participating  line  ministries  are  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry; Ministry of Commerce; Ministry of Education, Youth and 
Sports (MOEYS); Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy; Ministry of Rural Development; and 
Ministry of Social Affairs, Labor, Vocational Training and Youth Rehabilitation (MOSALVY). All 
are directly involved in employment generation. A memorandum of understanding will be drawn 
up between MOWVA and these line ministries for the TA. 
 
6.  Close cooperation and coordination among aid agencies and executing agencies of 
projects and programs will be critical. Several capacity building projects with MOWVA are 
ongoing. Notable among these are the International Labor Organization (ILO) and Japan Asian 
Regional  Project,  the  Expansion  of  Employment  Opportunities  for  Women  (EEOW);  the 
Partnership for Gender Equity (formerly Partnership for Building Together) financed by the 
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the Government of the Netherlands; 
SEILA5 financed by UNDP, Department for International Development (United Kingdom), and 
Swedish  International  Development  Cooperating  Agency;  and  the  Integrated  Economic 
Empowerment, Entrepreneurship and Employment for Women (NEEEW) in Cambodia assisted 
by Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ). The TA will build on the 
achievements  of  these  projects  and  complement  the  gender  training  being  conducted  for 
MOWVA with training for staff in the participating line ministries.  
 
7.  The Government has well-defined policy and strategic plans in (i) the National Policy for 
Women (1996); Neary Rattanak, “Women are Precious Gems” (1999), and in the Second Socio-
Economic  Development  Plan  (2001–2005).  Capacity  building  must  be  considered  within 
MOWVA  and  line  ministries  must  be  initiated  into  mainstreaming  gender  and  women 
empowerment into their activities. The TA is the first phase of a recommended program to 
address the economic empowerment of women in Cambodia. The second phase will be the 
application of the knowledge built in the line ministries to actual programs for employment 
promotion among women on a pilot scheme.  
 
8.  The TA is consistent with ADB’s CSP update (2003-2005). The TA is necessary and 
timely  and  will  contribute  to  the  overall  goal  of  reducing  poverty  through  the  economic 
empowerment of women, especially the poor, widows, single parents, migrants, working women 
and those at risk.  
 
9.  In the design of the TA, a number of issues has been considered: (i) sociocultural 
constraints that continue to subordinate women, manifested in their limited occupational choices 
and in the gender gap in literacy and levels of educational attainment; (ii) very low levels of 
literacy in rural areas, so that programs directed at expanding employment opportunities for 
women should include training in functional literacy; (iii) growing pressures on agriculture that

to  the  need  for  more  emphasis  on  developing  and  strengthening  alternative  livelihood

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  In support of the Government’s goal of reducing poverty, the goal of the TA is to 
contribute to the economic empowerment of disadvantaged women in the rural areas, especially 
the poor, widows, single parents, working women, and migrants. The TA will strengthen the 
capacity of MOWVA to manage its mandate of gender mainstreaming at the provincial and 
commune  levels  (through  the  provincial  departments  of  women’s  and  veterans’  affairs 
[PDWVA]). It will also strengthen the capacity of the six participating line ministries to generally 
manage gender mainstreaming and activities in their sectors, and specifically to implement 
employment generation schemes under the TA. It will build on the achievements of the previous 
TA and align capacity-building efforts along the decentralized system6 being implemented. It will 
cover to the extent possible, organizations and agencies that are involved in such work, e.g., the 
Cambodian Union Federation, Employers’ Federation, Cambodian National Council for Women, 
and NGOs.  
 
11.  Key outputs will include (i) a situation analysis of the existing management system and 
capacity to mainstream gender at the provincial offices of MOWVA and at the six line ministries; 
(ii) action plans for supporting strategic planning, monitoring, and evaluation; (iii) a labor market 
information  database;  (iv)  training  materials  on  entrepreneurship  development  and 
microenterprise  development;  (v)  market  research  methodologies  and  tools;  (vi)  strategic 
framework for micro and small enterprise development and support; and (vii) ministry strategies 
in support of economic empowerment of women.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will cover geographical areas and activities in 8 provinces not already covered 
by projects of other aid agencies. Activities will be centered in the line ministries (central and 
provincial/commune levels) with oversight by MOWVA and the consultants. The TA will have 
three major components: (i) strengthening capacity in advocacy for employment promotion in 
MOWVA  and  the  six  line  ministries  through  training;  (ii)  development  of  approaches  and 
materials  for  strengthening  women’s  employment  opportunities  (labor  market  information, 
entrepreneurship  development  and  microenterprise  management,  training  programs,  and 
product marketing); and, (iii) strengthening capacity in policy formulation and networking (micro 
and small enterprise development, models and best practices, and networking).  
 
13.  Advocacy  for  Economic  Empowerment  of  Women.  Activities  will  include 
(i) information  and  data  gathering  about  and  analyses  of  gender  concerns  in  employment, 
directed at influencing policy formulation and integration of gender concerns into national and 
sectoral policies and programs; (ii) identification of gender-specific concerns in employment 
promotion for women through the PDWVAs and local governments in the selected provinces;

and (iii) strengthening of systems and procedures within MOWVA for sectorwide management 
of women’s economic empowerment activities, such as aid coordination, external aid sourcing, 
and  interministerial  networking;  work  planning,  monitoring,  evaluation,  and  feedback;  and 
improving communication (English), management, and computing skills. 
 
14.  Development of Approaches and Materials. Activities include (i) establishment of a 
database for labor market information in collaboration with the National Institute of Statistics,  
with particular emphasis on the informal sector: data are to be segregated by gender, age, 
educational qualification, rural-urban setting, and province; (ii) development of methodologies 
and tools for identifying local products with market potential, and analyzing opportunities and 
constraints to developing these products from a gender perspective; (iii) development and field-
testing  of  teaching  and  learning  materials  on  women  entrepreneurship  development  and 
microenterprise management in collaboration with relevant line ministries and aid agencies; and 
(iv) support for development and testing of microenterprise and entrepreneurial training, training 
of trainers, employment services, and job counseling (in cooperation with MOEYS, MOSALVY, 
and women in development centers).  
 
15.  Policy Formulation and Networking. Activities include (i) formulating the micro and 
small  enterprise  development7  framework  for  MOWVA’s  strategic  plan;  (ii)  supporting  the 
establishment  of  a  framework  and  identifying  models  and  best  practices  to  support  the 
implementation of the National Policy for Women across the line ministries; (iii) assisting line 
ministries to formulate their strategies to support the economic empowerment of women; and 
(iv) developing networks with other ministries, aid agencies, NGOs, and other projects, among 
provinces and with other countries. 
 
16.  The anticipated outcomes from the TA will include (i) strengthened MOWVA’s capacity 
as  advocate,  catalyst,  and  facilitator  of  gender  mainstreaming  and  awareness  of  gender 
concerns among the line ministries, including planning, implementation, monitoring, evaluation, 
and feedback; (ii) improved MOWVA aid coordination, external aid sourcing, and interministerial 
networking; (iii) strengthened interdepartmental coordination mechanisms between MOWVA 
and PDWVAs; (iv) strengthened capacity of the line ministries to formulate policy and integrate  
gender concerns into their sector policies and programs; and (v) improved capability of MOWVA 
and line ministries at provincial, district, commune, and institutional levels for program planning, 
monitoring, and reporting, including technical and financial aspects. 
 
17.  For the TA, MOWVA must manage (i) a multiplicity of government implementing agencies 
(PDWVAs),  other  ministries  and  their  provincial  departments;  and  (ii)  complex  coordinating 
requirements between central and local governments, and with NGOs, projects/programs of aid 
agencies. ADB experience shows that such complex management requirements have resulted in 
problems in the sequencing and synchronizing activities and have strained interoffice relations. 
Thus, close supervision and monitoring of activities will be required. There is also a risk that 
adequate social capital may not be built. Key stakeholders, and their interests and power, needs 
and  demands,  and  willingness  to  participate  must  be  identified.  The  local  organizational 
capacity must be built through participatory processes to enhance people’s ability to work 
together, trust each other, mobilize resources, resolve conflicts, and network. Stakeholders 
must be provided with opportunities to make choices and options on the type of projects they 
want and given the authority to manage such projects. 
C.  Cost and Financing  
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $470,000 equivalent, comprising $300,000 in

foreign exchange and $170,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost, and $100,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis, from the Poverty 
Reduction Cooperation Fund. The Government will finance the balance of the local currency 
cost, equivalent to $70,000, through the provision of counterpart staff and training, workshops, 
administrative and support services, and office accommodation. The Government assured ADB 
of the availability of counterpart services, facilities, and funds. The detailed cost estimates and 
proposed financing arrangements are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MOWVA will be the Executing Agency and will coordinate activities closely with the six 
line ministries, agencies, and NGOs. The undersecretary of state will be the TA director and will 
have overall responsibility for the TA. Quarterly and annual reports summarizing the outcome of 
TA  activities  will  be  prepared.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  during  18  months  in  close 
coordination and collaboration with ILO (EEOW), NEEEW, UNDP’s Partnership for Gender 
Equity and SEILA, and GAD projects of other aid agencies. The TA will work in collaboration 
with  the  project  steering  committee  already  set  up  for  EEOW.  The  steering  committee  is 
comprised  of  11  full  members  and  11  back-up  members  representing  (i)  MOWVA;  (ii) 
MOSALVY; (iii) MOEYS; (iv) Ministries of Industry, Mining and Energy; (v) Ministry of Rural 
Development; (vi) Ministry of Commerce; (vii) Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fishery; (viii) 
the  Cambodian  Union  Federation;  and  (ix)  the  Employers’  Federation.  The  committee  will 
establish guidelines for the training and seminar programs and will meet every 6 months to 
review progress and resolve issues. 
20.  The  TA  will  require  a  total  of  30  person-months  of  consulting  services,  including 
12 person-months for an international consultant (institution development and management 
expert), and 18 person-months for a domestic consultant (human resource development and 
training  expert).  The  services  will  be  spread  over  the  project  implementation  period  of 
18 months  starting  in  November  2002  and  ending  in  April  2004.  The  two  experts  will  be 
engaged on an individual basis by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants.  Office  equipment  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Procurement. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
21.  The Government will provide a suitably qualified counterpart team of six staff to work 
with the consultants, as well as office accommodation for the project management team. Under 
the supervision of MOWVA, the team will implement the planned activities and outputs. The 
consultants will facilitate the functioning of the team, and provide intensive, on-the-job capacity 
building support. The consultants will also help develop training programs and conduct training 
workshops to be organized in accordance with arrangements satisfactory to ADB. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to the Government 
of Cambodia to be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund for the 
purpose of Sustainable Employment Promotion for Poor Women, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.
